subject: Re: [junit] test last
msgSnippet: Coolspot714  wrote on 23.09.2004 12:12:46: [snip] ... What are you writing the tests for? Do you want to check wether the system works
messageBody:
"Coolspot714" <Coolspot714@...> wrote on 23.09.2004 12:12:46:

[snip]
> It still isn't determined yet on which level the tests should take
> place. "Real unit-tests" ("test everything that could possibly break")
> would be too much work for the given time(~6 weeks), I guess. So it
> might be more something like acceptance tests.

What are you writing the tests for? Do you want to check wether the system
works or do you want to be able to refactor without fear of breaking
things?

I'd usually write tests for such a system on-demand. Only when a
code-change is needed or a bug found will I write a test. Large-scale
test-writing "because we should" is not worth it IMHO.

> Since we still have to exactly figure out what we want to test, I
> would appreciate some information about whether or not JUnit is the
> right choice in general (alternatives?) and some advices for my "test
> last" approach.

I've been using JUnit in a similar situation (I maintain/extend a
framework that was built without any UnitTests) and I've successfully used
JUnit for not-quite-unit Tests. Other tools have been suggested
(Fit/Fitnesse come to my mind) but I've not seen anything yet that makes
it worth to convert the 150+ Tests that exist.

> Thanks in advance,
> Thomas
